publisher: Leiden, The Netherlands ; Boston, MA : Brill
description: "The Golden Age of Mexican cinema is illuminated in this collection of popular movie periodicals. Not only does it include chief magazines such as Cinema Reporter (1943-1965) and Cine Mundial (1951-1955), it also features two extremely rare issues of El Cine Gráfico from 1935 and copies of the weekly El Mundo Ilustrado (1902-1910), an arts magazine that also contained notes on movies. The true extent of the popularity of Mexican film is illustrated by Cinelandia (1931-1947), which was published in Hollywood both in Spanish and in English. This collection also includes some fifty rare lobby cards, which were used to advertise a film. Finally, for the first time this collection gives access to the personal scrap book of Fernando de Fuentes (1894-1958), one of the leading Latin-American filmmakers to this day. It contains reviews, movie stills, programs, and advertisements, shedding a unique light on the career of this pioneering director."--Background Page.

Classic Mexican Cinema is a collection of popular movie periodicals, covering the "Golden Age" of Mexican Cinema. The resource includes chief magazines such as Cinelandia (1931-1947), which was published in both Spanish and English in Hollywood, Cinema Reporter (1943-1965) and Cine Mundial (1954-1955), with extremely rare copies of El Cine Gráfico from 1935 and of the weekly El Mundo Ilustrado (1902-1910). This collection also includes dozens of film flyers, as well as the personal scrap books of filmmaker Fernando de Fuentes (1894-1958). -- Description from NYU Libraries.

Classic Mexican Cinema is a collection of popular movie periodicals, covering the "Golden Age" of Mexican Cinema. The resource includes chief magazines such as Cinelandia (1931-1947), which was published in both Spanish and English in Hollywood, Cinema Reporter (1943-1965) and Cine Mundial (1954-1955), with extremely rare copies of El Cine Gráfico from 1935 and of the weekly El Mundo Ilustrado (1902-1910).
